Issues.Title: disable helix unit tests for now
Issues.Body:
Some unit tests are failing on helix machines that do not fail on the build machines. This change is to get us unblocked. We already run debug unit tests locally (for code coverage), so this is no different than what we already have, and integration tests are still running on helix.

Here's the fix from Matt Galbraith:

I’m pretty sure, having now run your test locally, what’s going on. Specifically, I think you’re running afoul of dialog handler, which is a thing we have on all the Helix Windows machines to dismiss things like modal invariant / debug assert dialogs and such.

We need this to prevent folks’ Checked and debug test runs from timing out and preventing logging of legitimate failures, but you need it to be gone. 

To disable it, you can choose to explicitly kill dhandler.exe running on the machine, or for fancier means consult this:
https://github.com/dotnet/core-eng/blob/master/Documentation/HelixDocumentation.md#disable-dialog-handler-windows-only

Ping me if you need any clarification.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "disable helix unit tests for now" (#1025)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: adding the ScrollItem pattern to ListBox items, fixing ListBox navigation by Narrator
Issues.Body:
fixes #932 and related to #1026.
The pull request adds new changes and replaces pull request #935.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Accessibility: adding the ScrollItem pattern to ListBox items, fixing ListBox navigation by Narrator" (#1027)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: While Narrator on, caps lock right arrow jumps out of list box prematurely
Issues.Body:
**Repro steps:**
- Using the Narrator with caps lock mode set focus to list box item.
- Press caps lock + right arrow to set focus to next list box item.

**Actual:**
The Narrator jumps out of the list box without traversing the complete list.

**Expected result:**
Using Narrator with caps lock mode set to an item, caps lock right arrow passes in order of the elements of the list up and down without jumping out of the list.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: While Narrator on, caps lock right arrow jumps out of list box prematurely" (#1026)

Issues.Title: do not include xlf files in the winforms templates
Issues.Body:
This is a fix for a regression in the WinForms templates. When they were ported to this repo these templates incorrectly include xlf files in the nuget packages for the templates.

Without the changes in this PR `dotnet new` will generate a bunch of unused files

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9797472/58121282-e4d86b00-7bbb-11e9-9bfe-a475aa769b62.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "do not include xlf files in the winforms templates" (#1020)

Issues.Title: Remove dead code relating to support for themes
Issues.Body:
The Themes feature is supported on operating systems since Windows Server 2003 (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/uxtheme/nf-uxtheme-isappthemed)

Importantly, this does *not* necessarily mean that visual styles are enabled, but that they are present in the feature set.

If you look at the implementation of the `OSFeature` check for themes, we don't actually check if `IsAppThemed` returns `true`, but rather that it does not throw.. More specifically we check that it does not throw a `EntryPointNotFoundException`, which won't happen in .NET Core since we're supported since Windows 7

The actual check for whether visual styles are enabled is `VisualStyleInformation.IsEnabledByUser`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove dead code relating to support for themes" (#1024)

Issues.Body: I understand that this is not enabled in winforms and actually isn't supported in .NET Core

Assert.Equal() Failure\r\nExpected: True\r\nActual:   False
   at System.Windows.Forms.Tests.BindingContextTests.BindingContext_Contains_DataSource_ReturnsExpected(BindingContext context, Object dataSource, Boolean expected) in /_/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/UnitTests/System/Windows/Forms/BindingContextTests.cs:line 372
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Flaky Test: BindingContext_Contains_DataSource_ReturnsExpected" (#1017)

Issues.Title: MenuStrip constructor throwing exception
Issues.Body:
I don't know if this actually has anything to do with this repo itself. The error actually gets thrown from System.Drawing.Common. Let me know if I should post this over there instead.

When my Designer.cs file news-up a MenuStrip (`this.nav = new System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip()`), the following exception is thrown:

`System.TypeInitializationException: 'The type initializer for 'Gdip' threw an exception.'

TypeLoadException: Could not load type 'System.Runtime.InteropServices.NativeLibrary' from assembly 'System.Runtime.InteropServices, Version=4.2.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a'.`

Again, the `Source` of this exception is System.Drawing.Common, so let me know if this is unrelated to this repo. Also, note that the project builds without errors. This only happens at runtime.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MenuStrip constructor throwing exception" (#1015)

Issues.Body: Extracted from https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1012

Issues.Title: Cleanup VisualStyleInformation interop
Issues.Body:
- Avoid allocated a large `StringBuilder`. Instead use a stackallocated span. 512 is an appropriate size for stack allocation
- Move to the `Interop.XYZ` model to match .NET Foundation interop guidelines
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Cleanup VisualStyleInformation interop" (#1012)

Issues.Title: Visual Studio doesn't support ILProtector project files
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: (e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info`)
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   2.2.105
 Commit:    7cecb35b92

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.18362
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.2.105\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 2.2.3
  Commit:  6b8ad509b6

.NET Core SDKs installed:
  2.2.105 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

.NET Core runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.All 2.2.3 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.All]
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 2.2.3 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 2.2.3 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: N/A

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**
When you open the project file for Winforms it throws a warning saying that Accessibility.ilproj is unsupported.

I have opened this up in VS 2013 and VS 2015 they both show it as being unsupported as well.
The warning I pasted is from

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

_Note: This warning was thrown in VS 2015 Community even though it says it can be opened in VS 2015_

Unsupported
This version of Visual Studio is unable to open the following projects. The project types may not be installed or this version of Visual Studio may not support them. 
For more information on enabling these project types or otherwise migrating your assets, please see the details in the "Migration Report" displayed after clicking OK.
	 - Accessibility, "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\GitHub\winforms\src\Accessibility\src\Accessibility.ilproj"


No changes required
These projects can be opened in Visual Studio 2015, Visual Studio 2013, Visual Studio 2012, and Visual Studio 2010 SP1 without changing them.
	 - WinformsControlsTest, "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\GitHub\winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\tests\IntegrationTests\WinformsControlsTest\WinformsControlsTest.csproj"
	 - System.Windows.Forms, "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\GitHub\winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System.Windows.Forms.csproj"
	 - System.Windows.Forms.Tests, "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\GitHub\winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\tests\UnitTests\System.Windows.Forms.Tests.csproj"
	 - System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors, "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\GitHub\winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors.csproj"

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Visual Studio doesn't support ILProtector project files" (#1009)

Issues.Title: Remove all Instances of System.Configuration
Issues.Body:
From email thread:

> In .NETCore we don’t recommend the use of app.config (none of the framework types honor its settings) nor does machine.config exist. 

> App.config doesn’t flow into AppContext since CoreCLR doesn’t read app.config.  AppContext still exists and you can access the values via the API.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove all Instances of System.Configuration" (#1007)

Issues.Title: Refactor ResolvedMatchingContract calculation
Issues.Body:
Changes to the build caused ResolveMatchingContract to run after
conflict resolution which was removing the desktop reference to
System.Drawing in preference to the one in the NETCoreApp refs.

Avoid this completely by directly setting ResolvedMatchingContract
using the path to the targeting pack package.

Alternative to https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1005 that doesn't include arcade update.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Refactor ResolvedMatchingContract calculation" (#1006)
